data.title: Hawks have interest in free agent Dampier
data.text:
Atlanta Hawks general manager Billy Knight and coach Mike Woodson met with free agent center Erick Dampier Monday in Salt Lake City, a team spokesman said.

Hawks vice president of communications Arthur Triche confirmed Knight and Woodson met privately with Dampier in Utah, where the Hawks' summer league team is playing this month.

Dampier, a 6-foot-11 center who averaged 12.3 points and 12.0 rebounds last season, is weighing interest from the Hawks against a sign-and-trade offer from the New York Knicks.

The Hawks have re-signed center Jason Collier, who played in 20 games with the team late last season, and have added forward Al Harrington in a sign-and-trade deal with the Indiana Pacers. Collier provides depth, but the 260-pound Dampier would give the team a needed physical presence in their starting lineup.

The Hawks were denied in another attempt to bolster their front court when free agent forward Kenyon Martin turned down their six-year, $85 million offer to accept a similar deal with Denver last week.

The Hawks have the advantage of more salary cap room than most teams, including New York, in their efforts to sign the 30-year-old Dampier as a free agent. The Knicks have a deeper roster than the Hawks from which to talk trade with Golden State.

Golden State executive vice president of basketball operations Chris Mullin is pushing for a sign-and-trade deal with Dampier.

The Knicks have offered former Hawks center Nazr Mohammed and Othella Harrington for Dampier and would offer Dampier a six-year contract starting at $9 million per year, the New York Post reported. Dampier would have to accept the contract offer before agreeing to a trade.

"Nothing is imminent right now," Mullin said Monday. "We're talking about a lot of different scenarios. The good thing is there's really not a time frame. We have a lot of different options."

Dampier, a Mississippi native who was a standout at Mississippi State, could be closer to his home by signing with Atlanta, but he reportedly has concerns about the Hawks' chances to be a contender in the near future.

Under Knight, Woodson and a new ownership group, the Hawks had only five players on their roster entering the recent NBA draft.
